did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Manuscript handbooks of cures for illnesses and wounds to livestock, mainly cows and horses.

bioghist.p: James Goodwin was a veterinarian, born in England in 1778, who came to America in 1830. He and his wife Ann settled in Geneva, New York, where they remained until their deaths, in 1859 and 1866 respectively.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Manuscript handbooks of cures for illnesses and wounds to livestock, mainly cows and horses. The French manuscript (1617) is by Charles Fontaine, and is written in the form of a dialogue between a boy and his father. The small English manuscript with a printed political cartoon on the cover belonged to James Goodwin and dates from the 1790s. The two large manuscripts by Benjamin Lock, A book of cures both physical and chirurgical for horses and A book of cures both physical and chirurgical for cows, also date from the 1790s. The German manuscript (1816) is anonymous. It includes notes on family anniversaries and medicine for humans as well as veterinary medicine.

Also, a handbook compiled by S.H. McCoy of Monticello, New York, consisting of newspaper clippings and manuscript notes on cures for illnesses and wounds to livestock, as well as manuscript records of financial transactions (circa 1874-1879); and a handbook of manuscript "recipes" for veterinary cures kept by W.S. Smith of North Monroe, New Hampshire (1886).

note.p: Remedies for cattle and horses. A printed political cartoon on the front cover has caption "The political rat catcher." Note on the inside back cover on the birth date of Ann Downs, May 21, 1785; notes on financial transactions at end are dated 1796.
Remedies and instructions for treatment of horses and cattle, mainly horses. Front cover lacking; index at the end.
Manuscript belonging to Charles Fontaine, with treatments mainly for horses, given in the form of a dialogue between a boy and his father.
